title: Ticket #482: Thread Local storage breaks cross tests from 32b rhel 3->64 bit rhel3
description:
When thread support was merged, the cross test failed from 32 bit rhel 3 to 64 bit rhel3. All other combinations seem to work. The tests fail early, in remote_pre, because condor_config_val (and all the tools) core dump on startup when trying to initialize dprintf.

Running condor_config_val under gdb shows the following: 

Program received signal SIGSEGV, Segmentation fault.
_condor_dprintf_va (flags=4096, fmt=0x82c3ba0 "config: using subsystem '%s', local '%s'\n",args=0xffff96a8 "\200u7\b\231;,\b\bu7\bN\032@�\002@\"\016\b\bu7\b\bu7\b\034\026 @\bu7\b\bu7\b�@�\a@\"\016\bps7\b\bu7\b>I\a@�\001@�020\002")

    at dprintf.c:201

201                     CurrentTid = 0;

and gdb seems confused about TLS:
(gdb) p CurrentTid
Cannot find thread-local variables on this target

I've disabled this cross test for the moment, when this test is resolved the 32 bit rhel3 -> 64 bit rhel3 test should be re-enabled.
remarks:
2009-May-15 06:32:01 by tannenba:
It seems more serious than just x86_64_rhas. We observed very strange behavior (gdb crashing, master just stopping) on SL4.6. For v7.3.1, going to disable linking in of pthreads/TLS all together, and then get rid of TLS for 7.3.2.

2009-May-15 09:25:29 by gthain:
We need to read the drepper white paper at http://people.redhat.com/drepper/tls.pdf

Note that C98 adds support for the __thread storage specifier, perhaps that would be a better implementation?

There's gcc options that might help: 

-mtls-direct-seg-refs
-mno-tls-direct-seg-refs
    Controls whether TLS variables may be accessed with offsets from the TLS segment register (%gs for 32-bit, %fs for 64-bit), or whether the thread base pointer must be added. Whether or not this is legal depends on the operating system, and whether it maps the segment to cover the entire TLS area.

    For systems that use GNU libc, the default is on.


-ftls-model=model
    Alter the thread-local storage model to be used (see Thread-Local). The model argument should be one of global-dynamic, local-dynamic, initial-exec or local-exec.

    The default without -fpic is initial-exec; with -fpic the default is global-dynamic.

2009-Aug-17 08:34:06 by tannenba:
Re the remark above - good thinking, and looks promising, but I have to say having been burned on TLS once I am shy to try another iteration of it again.

2009-Aug-17 08:41:01 by tannenba:
So one of the more subtle and annoying aspects of getting rid of the thread local storage is dealing w/ the recursive nature of dprintf(). dprintfs() happens all over Condor, including in the hashtable template etc. And yet dprintf() wants to display the tid. So we are left with some choices:
  1. Deal w/ the recursive nature of the above by being able to detect a re-entrancy into dprintf and making it a no-op, or
  2. Use pthread keys to give us the same mechanism as TLS, and stash the tid in the key.
